before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"5pt4a","text":"A day prior to performing immunostaining, prepare your BSA-coated tubes. Add 1mL of 10% BSA solution in ice cold 1x PBS (RNAse-free) to autoclaved 1.5mL Eppendorf tubes (one for each planned nuclei sample). Incubate them for 10 minutes on ice. Rinse them with ice cold 1x PBS (RNAse-free) and let them dry at 4oC overnight (open lid).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":6,"length":5},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":324,"length":8},{"style":"sup","offset":310,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8dr8j","text":"A day prior to performing FANS, prepare your coated collection tubes. Add 500uL of ice cold 1x PBS (RNAse-free) solution, 25uL of RNAse Inhibitor (40U/uL), and 500uL of 10% BSA solution to your autoclaved and prechilled 1.5mL LoBind Eppendorf tubes that you will be using to collect your sorted nuclei samples (you should create at least 2 tubes for each sample: one for NeuN+ nuclei and one for NeuN- nuclei. It is recommended to make at least 4 tubes for each sample to better prevent potential overflow of sorted nuclei). Close lids and gently invert tubes a few times. Incubate tubes on ice for 10 minutes. Rinse each tube with 1mL ice cold 1x PBS (RNAse-free) and let it dry at 4oC overnight (open lid).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":6,"length":5},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":329,"length":8},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":698,"length":8},{"style":"sup","offset":684,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9odtd","text":"There is a need for disentangling the role of transcriptional and epigenetic variation in mental health, disease, and mortality. Although alterations in DNA methylation patterns have been found to be particularly stable and highly concentrated in the brain, the study of bulk tissue, which contains several types of cells, can be limited and potentially significantly mask different alterations driven by specific cell types. Therefore, there is a need for methods to be able to purify specific cell-type populations that can be used in downstream molecular analyses. This protocol describes a methodology that uses fluorescence-activated nuclei sorting (FANS) to overcome these limitations and analyze, specifically, neuronal nuclei from frozen post-mortem prefrontal cortex tissue. Specifically, this protocol was based on recently-published protocols with the same goal with adaptations that have proven to improve yield and quality of the samples in our laboratory using the BD FACSJazzTM cell sorting system. To our knowledge, this is the only published protocol where a methodology for a flow cytometry instrument with a manual laser and sorting alignment is described in detail. This method can be used to purify populations of neuronal (NeuN+) and non-neuronal (NeuN-) nuclei from adult frozen post-mortem brain tissue, with tissue samples yielding purified populations of nuclei amenable to be able to perform analyses of DNA methylation, genotyping, and potentially, open chromatin analysis (via ATAC-seq).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":990,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c8g7h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqn2r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"at2mn","text":"The protocol below yields at least 300,000 NeuN+ and NeuN- nuclei (when the population is present) per    of frozen human post-mortem prefrontal cortex tissue. It is important to note that recovery may vary from sample to sample due to high inter-sample variability. Refer to Tables 1, 2, and for details about equipment items that are required and for the specifications of the reagents that are required for each section of this protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":103,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"61lkg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":40,"offset":98}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":42,"offset":98,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"italic"}],"key":"42ke1","text":"(Note: Part A of this protocol is based on the protocol created by the Cobos Lab in October 2019 (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.6tuhenw, based on Krishnaswami et al., Nat Protoc. 2016;11(3):499-524). While the original protocol was created for single-soma RNAseq experiments, this version of the protocol has been adapted for production of quality DNA from nuclei sorted from FACS.)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"6797B9C5F1A211ECA7AF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.6tuhenw"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"100","error":false,"guid":"C459B530F19411EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":5}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e46ej","text":"Prepare Homogenizing Buffer (HB) solution and keep it  . Pre-chill (i.e., Fast temp) your centrifuge to   before starting. Make sure that homogenizers and pestles are pre-chilled and sitting    before use. Place the autoclaved forceps and scalpel at  . (Note: you can also place a Petri dish on dry ice, if you would like to chop up the brain sample into smaller pieces before transfer). {"blocks":[{"key":"ce1mb","text":"Weigh Eppendorf tubes with sample tissue (you want around  ) of sample tissue to be placed in each homogenizer (keep these at  ).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":58,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":126,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d71r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"100","error":false,"guid":"D36FB510F19411EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":5}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"BCF63EA0F18D11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"on dry ice","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3re9n","text":"Transfer the 100mg brain chunks to their corresponding homogenizers (  ). Use the pre-chilled/frozen forceps and scalpel to help you do this.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":69,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eoecm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"C5C9C420F18D11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7dnk4","text":"While  , place 600uL of Homogenizing Buffer into each homogenizer. Use 600uL of Homogenizing Buffer to “wash out” the tubes that contained the tissues 3 times (if the tissue came out of multiple tubes, wash out each tube once or twice (i.e., 600uL of Homogenizing Buffer to wash out the tube twice)). This helps make sure that you are getting as much of the tissue as possible out of the Eppendorf tubes. Your homogenizer should have a final volume of around 2.4mL of Homogenizing Buffer in them (plus the brain tissue sample) once this process is done.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":6,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"12n7a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"CEB47B20F18D11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ari8o","text":"Use a spray of RNaseZapTM on a KimwipeTM to lightly wipe the pestle before using it to homogenize (Note: Make sure it is dry before using it to administer your manual strokes). With the homogenizer in a beaker of ice   , administer 30 slow and gentle manual strokes to homogenize the tissue using the pestle to move the pestle up and down, using a gentle grinding motion when touching the bottom of the homogenizer tube. (Note: Try not to lift the pestle completely out of the liquid, as this will create bubbles and foaming, which can cause problems).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":23,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":38,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":217,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bannk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"09607850F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"s76p","text":"Once this homogenizing is complete, use a hemocytometer (10uL of sample + 10uL of Trypan Blue) to check whether there are still remaining clumps (or whether too many strokes have been administered). If there are cell clumps visible, then this means you must administer more manual strokes (too few strokes administered). However, beware because too many strokes can result in damaged nuclei.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7hsfc","text":"Use sterile cell strainer caps to filter the homogenate from each homogenizer into a 15mL Falcon Tube  . ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":102,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9d6hf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6lpi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5s4hj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cj8sd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"29C68990F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"italic"}],"key":"91mhb","text":"(Note: Just hold the cell strainer cap on top of the Falcon tube’s opening and make circular movements while filtering the homogenate into the Falcon tube. Feel free to use multiple cell strainer tubes if you are having trouble getting the full sample through just one cell strainer.)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c5g49","text":"Take an aliquot (10uL) to check the sample for nuclei and removal of debris using the hemocytometer again (10uL of sample + 10uL of Trypan Blue).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3vpr0","text":"Repeat steps 8-9 (   and  ) several times to try to remove as much debris as possible (around 1 to 3 times, checking with a hemocytometer for appearance of nuclei and removal of debris each time).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":18,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":25,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9mh1k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"gotostep","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5CF47F20F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"step_guid":"FCB5DDD1ED9511ECA7D8814F5532A19A","title":""}},"1":{"type":"gotostep","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"62D2E080F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"step_guid":"FCB78B80ED9511ECA7D8814F5532A19A","title":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"as27d","text":"Separate filtered homogenate samples into 2 pre-chilled autoclaved 1.5mL LoBind Eppendorf tubes (4 tubes used if running 2 samples of tissue (100mg each); if running only 1 sample, split homogenate into 2 pre-chilled autoclaved LoBind Eppendorf tubes )). Make sure to evenly transfer sample(s) into tubes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":251,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fj4h7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"8AB4AF70F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9nvkf","text":"Centrifuge tubes at 1000rcf for 8 minutes at 4oC.   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":46,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":50,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43kfq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"centrifuge","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"centrifuge":"1000","duration":480,"error_centrifuge":false,"error_temperature":false,"guid":"907EEC90F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"scientificNotation":{"centrifuge":false,"temperature":false},"start":null,"temperature":"4","temperatureUnit":10,"unit":1324}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3qtmj","text":"Gently discard the supernatant from the tubes   . Try your best not to disturb the pellets (it is okay to leave just a small amount of liquid in the tubes, if it is not possible to get it all out without disruption of the pellet).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":46,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"anpn5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A94F2870F18E11EC9B9381C2FCFFB6C9","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":165}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"67pr3","text":"Gently resuspend each pellet in each tube in 225uL of cold Homogenization Buffer   . Once resuspended, pool split tubes back together   . Do this by placing the pooled resuspended liquid into a prechilled 2mL LoBind Eppendorf tube (1 tube for each original sample)   . {"blocks":[{"key":"5r1rr","text":"A day prior to performing FANS, prepare your coated collection tubes   . steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6tpsl","text":"Change all of the PMTs, FSC, and SSC to a log-scale by clicking the “log” checkboxes next to the PMT threshold adjustments and change the key threshold to FSC and around 1.65. (Note: FSC and SSC do NOT always have to be switched to log-scale. If easy visualization and gating can be done without switching FSC and SSC to log-scale, then this can also be done). Additionally, set the Sample Offset (in the Pressure Console) so that you get an Events per Second of around 200 when working with ALL of your samples (see Figure 6).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":42,"length":3},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":198,"length":3},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":232,"length":3},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":470,"length":3},{"style":"italic","offset":177,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":517,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etecv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5j72","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"brdif","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4pi5n","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"66kvq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"italic"}],"key":"12cj","text":"(Note: These can all be adjusted (as well as all PMTs and the threshold) as much as you want to get the best-looking plot. steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4jc7j","text":"First, start with sample #1 (the Unstained Control sample). Remove any tube from the sample tube area within the machine and click Backflush. Wait about 30 seconds and then click Backflush again to turn off the backflushing. Lightly vortex your already filtered sample with the vortexer (setting at 1) for about 10 seconds. Bring the sample back to the flow cytometer, place it in the sample tube area, and lock it in place. Press the Sample button for the sample to start being inputted into the flow cytometer’s system. Adjust your Default Display Count on the computer to around 1,000 and your Event Limit to around 2,000 (These can be found within the leftmost panel on your screen). Press the Boost button to get the sample flowing quicker into the system until you start seeing your Events Per Second change, as well as data starting to show up on your dot plots. Adjust your Sample Offset (and, if necessary, your PMT thresholds) until you get a consistent flow of about 200 events per second.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":33,"length":17},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":299,"length":1},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":534,"length":21},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":582,"length":5},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":597,"length":11},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":619,"length":5},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":978,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":131,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":179,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":435,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":698,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9i6h5","text":"This is the sample that you will most likely use for “cells” gating and gating out doublets: you will use an SSC vs. FSC plot to gate out debris (“Cells” gating plot) and a Trigger Pulse Width vs. FSC plot to gate out doublets (“Singlets” gating plot). (Note: Sometimes, the plots do not look consistently similar to what is normal or as good as they should for gating these two things (Figure 7). If this is the case and you are really having trouble discerning these things, you can move on and use sample #2 (the Hoechst Control sample) to give you a better idea and, in the worst case, to use for gating these 2 things).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":254,"length":4},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":254,"length":4},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":516,"length":15},{"style":"bold","offset":387,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3sru2","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fql4o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"01354E90EE5E11ECA7D8814F5532A19A","height":551,"id":258606,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"75gkm","text":"Figure 7. Depiction of how to perform the initial “cells” gating for your sample. The top two figures show what the plots should normally look like. The bottom two figures depict what the plots may look like when the FACS machine is acting up. It may be useful at this point to re-align the lasers, etc. and try to analyze your sample again, or shut off the machine and try again another day.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 7.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tsbur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tqbur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6trbur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tpbur47.webp","width":539}}}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"32d87","text":"For the “Cells” gating, make a plot with SSC on the y-axis and FSC on the x-axis. Now, using one of the gating tools in the upper toolbar (Figure 8), click and drag to create a square gate in this plot and name it “Cells.” Generally, the debris is usually found in the lower left-hand corner of the plot. Sometimes, you are able to see 2 different populations (one that is the debris and one that is the “cells”), but this is not always the case. Use your judgment to make this gate. We have now, theoretically, gated out any debris for our sorting sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":139,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6hsj","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"57sen","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8B8962A0EE6F11ECA7D8814F5532A19A","height":111,"id":258610,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"e9lm2","text":"Figure 8. A screenshot of where to find the button within the BD sortware software to be able to create a square gate for your plots.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 8.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6twbur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tubur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tvbur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6ttbur47.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8sjre","text":"For the “Singlets” gating, make a plot with Trigger Pulse Width on the y-axis and FSC on the x-axis. (Note: This plot is usually already made for you as the 3rd plot on your workspace). For this plot, we are trying to gate out the doublets (the clumped “cells” or aggregates). These typically appear a bit “bigger” than normal singlets and, therefore, have a greater Trigger Pulse Width. Using the same gating tool as above, click and drag to create a square gate in this plot and name it “Singlets.” Use your judgment to make this gate. (Tip: Do not worry if you are not entirely sure, we recommend doing a “double check” plot with the Hoechst Control sample to make sure that your “Singlets” gate is working somewhat properly). We have now, theoretically, gated out any doublets and larger aggregates from our sorting sample. Make sure that your “Singlet” gate is nestled under your “Cells” gate by placing it within that “Cells” gate order (Figure 9).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":102,"length":4},{"style":"italic","offset":539,"length":3},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":102,"length":4},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":539,"length":3},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":637,"length":15},{"style":"bold","offset":944,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2l6bu","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"24nr7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0DD7B130EE7011ECA7D8814F5532A19A","height":417,"id":258614,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"55f66","text":"Figure 9. Two examples of roughly what your “singlet” plot should look like. Within the top figure, you can see exactly how your gating hierarchy should be organized in the sortware software.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 9.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t2bur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tybur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6tzbur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6txbur47.webp","width":550}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6sjr2","text":"Now, remove sample #1 (the Unstained Controlsample) from the sample tube area and click Backflush to clear out the system of the sample. Wait 30 seconds before clicking Backflush again. We will now move onto sample #2 (the Hoechst Control sample). Remove any tube from the sample tube area within the machine and click Backflush. Wait about 30 seconds and then click Backflush again to turn off the backflushing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":27,"length":17},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":223,"length":15},{"style":"bold","offset":88,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":169,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":319,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":367,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fb0bs","text":"Lightly vortex your already filtered Hoechst Control sample with the vortexer (setting at 1) for about 10 seconds (Make sure that it is concealed with aluminum foil when you do this, as it has fluorescent dye in it). Bring the sample back to the flow cytometer, remove the aluminum foil, place it in the sample tube area, and lock it in place. Place some aluminum foil, as best you can, around the sample tube area to keep out any light. Press the Sample button for the sample to start being inputted into the flow cytometer’s system. Adjust your Default Display Count on the computer to around 10,000and your Event Limit to around 2,000 (these can be found within the leftmost panel on your screen). Press the Boost button to get the sample flowing quicker into the system until you start seeing your Events Per Second change, as well as data starting to show up on your dot plots. Adjust your Sample Offset (and, if necessary, your PMT thresholds) until you get a consistent flow of about 200 events per second.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":37,"length":15},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":90,"length":1},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":115,"length":99},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":344,"length":92},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":547,"length":21},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":595,"length":6},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":610,"length":11},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":632,"length":5},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":991,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":448,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":711,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"94as9","text":"This is the sample that you will use for identifying your “nuclei” gating and to also perform a “double check” of whether we have correctly identified “single nuclei” within our gating process. We will use a 520/35[405] vs. 450/50[405] plot to identify and gate nuclei (this is generally called the “Nuclei” gating plot). We will also use a 450/50[405] vs. FSC plot to perform a “double check” to see if our gating correctly identifies single nuclei.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asem6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgav1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3h2mq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":2,"style":"italic"},{"length":4,"offset":2,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"962aq","text":" (Note: We usually don’t use this plot for gating, but it could be potentially used for gating, if you wanted to.)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6m1ds","text":"For the “Nuclei” gating, make a plot with 520/35[405] on the y-axis and 450/50[405] on the x-axis. Now, using one of the gating tools in the upper toolbar, click and drag to create a square gate in this plot and name it “Nuclei.” The nuclei should have a high fluorescence at this wavelength, so they are typically found in the upper right-hand corner of the plot. Usually, you will actually see a distinct separate population here in that upper right quadrant. Those are your nuclei. Use your judgment to make this gate. We have now, theoretically, identified and gated our nuclei for our sorting sample. Sometimes, the populations can look a bit different (Figure 10). Make sure that your “Nuclei” gate is nestled under your “Singlets” gate by placing it within that “Singlets” AND “Cells” gates order (Figure 10).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":659,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":805,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dgui","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"divep","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"91581720EE7011ECA7D8814F5532A19A","height":416,"id":258618,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6vvnk","text":"Figure 10. Two examples of roughly what your “nuclei” plot should look like. Within the top figure, you can see exactly how your gating hierarchy should be organized in the sortware software.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 10.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t6bur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t4bur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t5bur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t3bur47.webp","width":543}}}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7dqp","text":"For the single nuclei “double check” plot, make a plot with 450/50[405] on the y-axis and FSC on the x-axis. Use this plot to observe the different populations. You should see at least 2 distinct populations start to populate this plot. The dots that are clustered high on the y-axis and also somewhat low on the x-axis are our single nuclei. If we have gated both our “Singlets” and our “Nuclei” gates properly, this distinct clustered population should be the same color as the nuclei gate that we made. If this is the case, then we have, theoretically, successfully gated Single Nuclei (Figure 11).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":575,"length":13},{"style":"bold","offset":590,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3rt9","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bbgfl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C9986B80EE7011ECA7D8814F5532A19A","height":246,"id":258622,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"f3iaf","text":"Figure 11. An example of roughly what your “double check” plot to check whether you have successfully gated all of your potential “Single Nuclei” should look like. Within the right part of the figure, you can see exactly how your gating hierarchy should be organized in the sortware software.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 11.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6uabur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t8bur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t9bur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6t7bur47.webp","width":429}}}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3fnb3","text":"This is the sample that you will use for identifying and gating for your “NeuN positive nuclei” and your “NeuN negative nuclei.” We will use a 530/40[488] vs. 450/50[405] plot to identify and gate both of these.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6l5r0","text":"For the “NeuN positive” and “NeuN negative” gating, make a plot with 530/40[488] on the y-axis and 450/50[405] on the x-axis. Now, using one of the gating tools in the upper toolbar, click and drag to create 2 square gates in this plot and name them “NeuN positive” and “NeuN negative”. The NeuN positive nuclei should be found high on the y-axis and high on the x-axis, while the NeuN negative nuclei should be found low on the y-axis but exactly as high on the x-axis. Sometimes, you will actually see distinct separate populations in the right-most upper and lower quadrants. You will, usually, be able to see at least one clear distinct population that has high fluorescence on the x-axis, but sometimes it can be a bit hard to differentiate between the two populations when it comes to y-axis. Use your own judgment to make this gate. We have now, theoretically, identified and gated our NeuN positive and NeuN negative nuclei for our sorting sample and are officially able to begin sorting. Make sure that your “NeuN positive” and “NeuN negative” gates are nestled under your “Nuclei” gate by placing it within your “Nuclei,” “Singlets,” AND “Cells” gates order (Figure 12).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":1169,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c25gp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n80t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f7cu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqfa","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6lk5j","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5kdih","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":16,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"}],"key":"7msil","text":"(Tip from our lab: If you cannot really differentiate between the 2 populations, try to make a cutoff gate (at the lowest) just above 10² on the y-axis. Denote anything found below this point as NeuN negative and anything found above this point as NeuN positive).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"UNDERLINE"},{"length":4,"offset":1,"style":"italic"},{"length":9,"offset":64,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8sh69","text":"(Note: Sometimes, the populations can look a bit different (see Figure 12).)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"CFF07440EE7111ECB9BEC37AB9BFFC78","height":354,"id":258626,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bprdq","text":"Figure 12.Two examples of roughly what your “NeuN positive Nuclei” vs. “NeuN negative Nuclei” plot should look like. steps.section: Part C1. Performing Gating of Samples and Sorting of Nuclei
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dnoot","text":"Watch the monitor and make sure to adjust your Sample Offset to keep your Event Rate to around 100-300 events per second. (Tip: Generally, keeping the Sample Offset at around 0.15 to 0.17 psi usually works well). Make sure that you can see droplets falling into your collection tubes. You should also be able to see small flickers of light on either side of the center waste stream on the 3rd camera picture on the computer screen (this means that droplets should be being deflected into your collection tubes) (Figure 14). Finally, make sure that you monitor your highest droplet breakoff point throughout the whole sorting process, in case it needs to be adjusted.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":95,"length":25},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":123,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":512,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b1aq","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bbsev","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2AE6F980EE7411ECB9BEC37AB9BFFC78","height":855,"id":258634,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"c42s9","text":"Figure 14. A screenshot of the Sortview portion of the sortware software that you can look at to make sure that your sorting is occurring properly. Always make sure that the hatch-marks portion of the middle figure contains that first breakoff point of the droplet; this may need to be adjusted sometimes during the sort, so make sure to be vigilant about this. Also make sure that you are seeing small flickers of light occurring on each side of the center waste stream. These flickers mean that your sample should be sorting into either the corresponding left or right tubes.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure 14.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6unbur47.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6ukbur47.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6umbur47.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h6ujbur47.webp","width":539}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b460k","text":"Make sure to lubricate the ring around the sheath fluid tank lid with Super O-Lube to get a good seal.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4icn2","text":"Make sure Drop Frequency is set to around 38.9 to 39.2. Try not to adjust this too much. Instead, you can adjust the height of the drops (using the silver knob on the top-right of the machine) and the Piezo Amplitude.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":42,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2k9fn","text":"Try to keep flow rate at a maximum of 1000 events per second and your efficiency at around 80+ %.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19qqq","text":"Once your Nuclei Sample tube has finished going through the FACSJazz, it can be also very useful to hit the Backflush button and let some sheath fluid run back into the tube. This will release some nuclei that were caught in the tubing system, but did not get analyzed or sorted. You can then hit the Sample button again and analyze these nuclei that were not initially analyzed. You can do this as many times as you want, until you do not see any more nuclei being detected on the monitor. We, generally, repeat this step about 3-5 times to try to get as many nuclei as possible, while also not allowing this to take too much time and contribute to potential sample degradation.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":108,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":301,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c26ip","text":"1000x DAPI (1.4uL) can be used in place of Hoechst 33342 dye, if not available. Both dyes have been used and tested in this protocol. However, it can be recommended in some cases, such as when using DAPI, or cases where the spectrums of your chosen fluorescent antibodies overlap, that auto-compensation is performed beforeperforming any gating or sorting. This can be done using this protocol by using the Unstained Control sample as your Negative Control, the Hoechst Control sample as your first single Positive Control, and either Alexa Fluor-488 mixed with UltraComp eBeads (following the bead manufacturer’s protocol) or staining part of the Unstained Control with Alexa Fluor-488 as your second single Positive Control.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":317,"length":6},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":317,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7v5i1","text":"If for any reason you are not able to perform FANS the same day as your immunostaining procedure, you can dissolve your pellets from Part B, Step #19 in 200uL-1000uL of Bambanker freezing medium using the following steps:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":55,"length":4},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":55,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ed0tg","text":"Dissolve pellet in 200uL-1000uL of Bambanker freezing medium by allowing pellet to dissolve for a few minutes on ice and then gently pipetting solution up and down gently.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ml81","text":"Transfer solution to a cryovial and place it in a Mr. Frosty overnight at -80oC.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":77,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rjph","text":"Store sample at -80oC for future use and analysis.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":19,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20upg","text":"Make sure to keep wrapped in aluminum foil as they will be photosensitive!","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb0ej","text":"In previous testing of protocols using the Qiagen AllPrep Kit, we have found it helpful to incubate both of our DNA and RNA filters in their designated elution buffers for about 3-5 minutes before performing the final centrifugation.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bm7r","text":"For DNA, we elute in 40uL of 64oC Buffer EB, and for RNA, we elute in 14uL of RNAse-free water. We have also found it useful to perform 2 separate elutions, which can be later combined and further concentrated using a SpeedVac machine.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":31,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
